body:
> So you are skimming. Or, you believe that Aratus, Menander, Epimenides, and a million others were also viewed as inspired. You would have no proof for that claim outside of assumptions, but hey, its your twisted logic.

No, I believe that the writers believed those *parts* were true. The only "inspired" kind of work is prophecy.

> Hanukkah, a holiday outlined outside of the Old Testament

In the apocryphal books of Maccabees.

> And another point on your contention Enoch may be Canon, it wasn't included in the Masoretic Texts, The Septuagint, or any known canon historically. It may have been read, but historically, the jews viewed it as separate from the canon of scripture.

The author of Jude would certainly disagree with you, seeing how he refers to it authoritatively. This is different from alluding to parts of writings as mentioned above. He quotes it for support of his claims, meaning he viewed it as factual. And you are right that *some* jews viewed it as fraudulent, but others saw it as true. In fact, a group of Jews called "Beta Israel" as well as Ethiopian Christians still consider Enoch scripture to this day. Thus my point, there was no canon, things were debated.

In fact, a group of Jews called "Beta Israel" as well as Ethiopian Christians still consider Enoch scripture to this day. Thus my point, there was no canon, things were debated.

parent.body:
"If that were the case you'd have to say Epimenides of Cnossoss was inspired XD If you consider quotes to be endorsements, then you're holding yourself to a different standard than others, the peak of hypocrisy."

So you are skimming. Or, you believe that Aratus, Menander, Epimenides, and a million others were also viewed as inspired. You would have no proof for that claim outside of assumptions, but hey, its your twisted logic.

Not to mention the quote in question is simply “Behold, the Lord came with many thousands of His holy ones”. This could easily be a case identical to Acts 20:35. A saying that was commonly known via tradition but not written into the scripture. As you put it earlier "Talmudic" in nature. And considering first Enoch was written in the 100s BC, its highly likely this was the case. This is not outside of Christian Orthodoxy, as Jesus himself celebrated Hanukkah, a holiday outlined outside of the Old Testament. Yet, Jesus himself opposed Talmudic rules and traditions constantly. 

In simple terms - referencing tradition is not the same as considering it inspired. 

And another point on your contention Enoch may be Canon, it wasn't included in the Masoretic Texts, The Septuagint, or any known canon historically. It may have been read, but historically, the jews viewed it as separate from the canon of scripture.

body: We have the testimony of tons of church fathers that Matthew was originally written in Hebrew. Moreover, textual analysis shows that this Hebrew version cannot be explained as a translation from the Greek, and for the most part really does represent a typical first century composition. It also contains readings from the Alexandrian text type and even the gospel of Thomas and Secret Mark, all of which had been LONG lost and forgotten by the time of Shem Tov so there's no way he could've put them there himself. In many places it makes more sense than the Greek. The only explanation is that this text is a descendant of the original Matthew. So aside from parts corrupted by Jewish scribes, or legitimate divergences that had been updated to match the Greek version more closely, this should actually be the more accurate text.
body_html: We have the testimony of tons of church fathers that Matthew was originally written in Hebrew. Moreover, textual analysis shows that this Hebrew version cannot be explained as a translation from the Greek, and for the most part really does represent a typical first century composition. It also contains readings from the Alexandrian text type and even the gospel of Thomas and Secret Mark, all of which had been LONG lost and forgotten by the time of Shem Tov so there's no way he could've put them there himself. In many places it makes more sense than the Greek. The only explanation is that this text is a descendant of the original Matthew. So aside from parts corrupted by Jewish scribes, or legitimate divergences that had been updated to match the Greek version more closely, this should actually be the more accurate text.

body:
> Jude referring to Enoch is the only one that's widely known and debunked so why bring it up?

It's not debunked. "Jude" here quotes Enoch literally word for word, and as an authoritative source. There's no other way to interpret this one. This one is not simply used to allude to or take an idea from a text, it quotes a prophecy.

> And claiming the Ezra similarity connotes canonicity faces an identical issue. You're treating a reference as if its an endorsement.

In most of the cases, sparing a few like the Enoch one, I'm not. But the point is that they're obviously familiar with such texts and find them useful. It does *not* mean they are perfect, only that they contain truth. Thus my point, because it shows how they treated "the writings", like written works *by people*, not dropped out of the sky by God (and the texts themselves mostly straight up say this). And this classification makes up most of the books in our biblical canon.

And no, the canon was not settled before 382 AD. Before that the legitimacy of different books was regularly disputed. That is historical fact. In fact the first "bible" compiled was by a gnostic!

Jude referring to Enoch is the only one that's widely known and debunked so why bring it up?

It's not debunked. "Jude" here quotes Enoch literally word for word, and as an authoritative source. There's no other way to interpret this one. This one is not simply used to allude to or take an idea from a text, it quotes a prophecy.

And claiming the Ezra similarity connotes canonicity faces an identical issue. You're treating a reference as if its an endorsement.

In most of the cases, sparing a few like the Enoch one, I'm not. But the point is that they're obviously familiar with such texts and find them useful. It does not mean they are perfect, only that they contain truth. Thus my point, because it shows how they treated "the writings", like written works by people, not dropped out of the sky by God (and the texts themselves mostly straight up say this). And this classification makes up most of the books in our biblical canon.

And no, the canon was not settled before 382 AD. Before that the legitimacy of different books was regularly disputed. That is historical fact. In fact the first "bible" compiled was by a gnostic!

parent.body:
Nothing you're saying is making sense. You believe it is, but its not. Assumptions, rhetorical questions, and framing the issues are not valid points. You're not making any.

For example, you claim the canon was made in 400, I just indicated that was not the case. Repeating my points to sidestep your flaws is tedious.

Jude referring to Enoch is the only one that's widely known and debunked so why bring it up? 1st Enoch is part of the Pseudepigrapha, so its by default not inspired. If that were the case you'd have to say Epimenides of Cnossoss was inspired XD If you consider quotes to be endorsements, then you're holding yourself to a different standard than others, the peak of hypocrisy.

And claiming the Ezra similarity connotes canonicity faces an identical issue. You're treating a reference as if its an endorsement. If that was the case, then John's reference to Logos would endorse the Greek meaning of the term. IN REALITY, John was referencing Logos are clarifying what it truly is. 

If a reference is an endorsement, then you'd have to read meaning into the text that is patently antithetical to the context. Beyond that, it would require a level of hypocrisy that I know you try to avoid.

Surely you know these things, so why do you create arbitrary standards for others, that you yourself do not follow?

body:
> CS Lewis is a random author, he is not an ancient tome from thousands of years ago tied to a long history of a resurging kingdom of believers.

Why does it have to be thousands of years old? Do you mean to say Jesus was just some random guy until 1000 AD? And I assume you believe no one but Jesus was ever perfect. If so, why do you still treat certain people as if they're infallible?

> Samaritan Pentateuch & Dead Sea Scrolls

Both of those prove my point. The Samaritans were one such group that accepted a certain canon of books, only Genesis, Exodus, Leviticus, Numbers, and Deuteronomy. Given that the rest of the old testament had been written by then, how does the Samaritan Pentateuch prove anything? And the Dead Sea Scrolls, well let's see here, we have Tobit, Enoch, Jubilees which you mentioned, the epistle of Jeremiah, a lost book of Noah, Sirach, and a whole host of books not included in our bible. Many of which are also referenced in the New Testament.

> its physically impossible for the NT to have copied the Talmud, because the Talmud was written from 300-500AD.

By "talmud" I mean whatever Judaic texts were circulating at the time. It doesn't have to be the same as the one they use today.

> I'd like to see a list of NT references to the apocrypha so I can study them

I can't spend all day on this but I'll provide you with a few.

Jude 1:14: Enoch, the seventh from Adam, also prophesied about them: “Behold, the Lord is coming with myriads of His holy ones to execute judgment on everyone, and to convict all the ungodly of every ungodly act of wickedness and every harsh word spoken against Him by ungodly sinners.”

1 Enoch 1:9: Behold, he comes with the myriads of his holy ones, to execute judgment on all, and to destroy all the wicked, and to convict all flesh for all the wicked deeds that they have done, and the proud and hard words that wicked sinners spoke against him.

4 Ezra 7: For I made the world for their sake, and when Adam transgressed my statutes, what had been made was judged. And so the entrances of this world were made narrow and sorrowful and toilsome; they are few and evil, full of dangers and involved in great hardships. But the entrances of the greater world are broad and safe, and yield the fruit of immortality. Therefore unless the living pass through the difficult and futile experiences, they can never receive those things that have been reserved for them.

Multiple NT allusions to the broad and narrow way

4 Ezra 7: For you have a treasure of works stored up with the Most High, but it will not be shown to you until the last times.

NT: Store up treasure in heaven

There are a LOT more, but you have to be looking in the right places, not the plethora of sites that try to twist it into saying they don't exist.

> There is so much you need to study and learn before judging others.

I haven't judged anyone here.

parent.body: Crystal, you're talking about things you know nothing about. CS Lewis is a random author, he is not an ancient tome from thousands of years ago tied to a long history of a resurging kingdom of believers. The canon existed long before the forming of the Vatican, such as via the Samaritan Pentateuch & Dead Sea Scrolls which date to 250BC minimum, with carbon dating indicating the latter is far older than even 400BC. I'd like to see a list of NT references to the apocrypha so I can study them, but I hope you're not planning to send vagueries like Solomon's Wisdom, where the references can be for literally anything. Beyond that, its physically impossible for the NT to have copied the Talmud, because the Talmud was written from 300-500AD. And if you mean to propose the Talmud was an oral tradition, you'd have a horde of scholars questioning you on the legitimacy of that claim, considering the very concept of such a thing didn't emerge until over 1000 years after Moses in spite of the claim he was the one who received it. To accept the Talmud as a hidden law you'd also have to accept the book of Jubilees, and nobody does that. There is so much you need to study and learn before judging others. Why lurk on the Christianity page only to get egg on your face? I can send you some resources if you'd like to learn more.

body:
> He changes scripture.

No more than anyone else is the bible did. I'd rather think people like Josiah and Ezra (or perhaps someone else slandering them) are the liars who changed scripture because it's obvious. Yeah, there was only one copy of such sacred scripture and they just "lost" it in a completely obvious spot. Sure they did, totally not just an excuse to make their forgeries look authentic. Or it was "burnt" and somehow that was the only copy in existence, giving Ezra an excuse to rewrite everything. Or maybe the "church fathers" who forged and edited new testament books at will.

> Lays all the worlds evil on women

I assume you're referring to 1 & 2 Timothy and Titus, and 1 Corinthians 11:3-16 and 14:34-35. Yeah, "Paul" here sounds pretty nasty, until you realize Timothy and Titus don't even fit the events of his life and contradict him on tons of points, and the 1 Corinthians passages are randomly interrupt in the middle of completely unrelated passages. The only real conclusion we can draw from Paul is Romans 16, which sounds nothing like those totally not forgeries. There's also Galatians 3:28, but it's possible that is also part of a later addition, though it still shows that the very early church when this was added would've supported such a statement.

> and dont protect their women

As if women need any more pampering than they already get. Men already do almost all the backbreaking work and sacrificing themselves while women sit around enjoying the fruits of their labor and cry to get whatever they want. The only thing they're actually expected to do in life is deal with kids if they have any. Everything else is made to make sure the women are always happy without the slightest grievance.

> Jesus words on jews being satanists are the strongest. Saul is a lying pharisee.

Jesus never said that. However an interpolation in one of Paul's letters does imply that (1 Thessalonians 2:14-16).
